title: British Rail Engineering Limited
text:
British Rail Engineering Limited (BREL) was the <a href="railway%20systems%20engineering">railway systems engineering</a> subsidiary of <a href="British%20Rail">British Rail</a>. Established in 1970, the maintenance arm was split as British Rail Maintenance Limited in 1987 and the design and building of trains was <a href="privatization">privatised</a> in 1989, purchased by the Swiss-Swedish conglomerate <a href="ABB">Asea Brown Boveri</a> (40%), <a href="Trafalgar%20House%20%28company%29">Trafalgar House</a> (40%), and a management-employee buy-out (20%). After <a href="ABB">ABB</a> became the sole shareholder it was subsumed into ABB Transportation.
History.
BREL was established by the <a href="British%20Railways%20Board">British Railways Board</a> on 1 January 1970 to take over the management of its 14 rolling stock maintenance centres including <a href="Ashford%20railway%20works">Ashford</a>, <a href="Crewe%20Works">Crewe</a>, <a href="Derby%20Litchurch%20Lane%20Works">Derby Litchurch Lane</a>, <a href="Derby%20Works">Derby Locomotive</a>, <a href="Doncaster%20Works">Doncaster</a>, <a href="Eastleigh%20Works">Eastleigh</a>, <a href="Glasgow%20Works">Glasgow</a>, <a href="Horwich%20Works">Horwich</a>, <a href="Shildon%20railway%20works">Shildon</a>, <a href="Swindon%20Works">Swindon</a>, <a href="Wolverton%20railway%20works">Wolverton</a>, and <a href="Holgate%20Road%20carriage%20works%2C%20York">York</a>. Ashford Works closed in 1981, Shildon in 1984, and Swindon in 1986. In 1987, Doncaster, Eastleigh, Glasgow, and Wolverton were transferred to BR Maintenance.
Not all British Rail rolling stock was built in-house: <a href="Brush%20Traction">Brush Traction</a>, <a href="Metro-Cammell">Metro-Cammell</a>, and <a href="Metropolitan-Vickers">Metropolitan-Vickers</a> amongst others manufactured rolling stock, although in general it was built to BREL specifications. Latterly, BREL often acted as a subcontractor to a main contractor such as <a href="General%20Electric%20Company">GEC</a>, which supplied traction equipment. These contracts required BREL to build the frames, body shells, and bogies, and install the traction and ancillary equipment of the primary contractor. Much of the electric locomotive construction programme of the 1980s, such as <a href="British%20Rail%20Class%2089">Classes 89</a>, <a href="British%20Rail%20Class%2090">90</a>, and <a href="British%20Rail%20Class%2091">91</a>, was carried out in this way.
As part of the <a href="privatisation%20of%20British%20Rail">privatisation of British Rail</a>, BREL was sold in a <a href="management%20buyout">management buyout</a>, with management and employees owning 20% and <a href="ABB">Asea Brown Boveri</a> and <a href="Trafalgar%20House%20%28company%29">Trafalgar House</a> 40% each. In 1991 Derby Locomotive Works closed. In March 1992, <a href="ABB">ABB</a> bought out the other shareholders with BREL subsumed into ABB Transportation in September 1992.
Products.
Multiple units.
BREL also produced some <a href="British%20Rail%20Railbuses">railbuses</a>.
Main products.
The vast majority of BREL's output was rolling stock for <a href="British%20Rail">British Rail</a>, including <a href="British%20Railways%20Mark%202">Mark 2</a> and <a href="British%20Rail%20Mark%203">Mark 3</a> carriages, the latter for locomotive haulage and <a href="InterCity%20125">InterCity 125</a> diesel High Speed Trains. BREL built the <a href="NIR%2080%20Class">NIR 80 Class</a> diesel-electric multiple units for <a href="NI%20Railways">Northern Ireland Railways</a>. Other Mark 3 derived vehicles included <a href="British%20Rail%20Class%20150">Class 150</a> diesel multiple units in the 1980s and numerous electric multiple units such as <a href="British%20Rail%20Class%20313">Classes 313</a> and <a href="British%20Rail%20Class%20317">317</a>.
BREL had success in the export market, notably with Mark 2 and Mark 3 carriages for <a href="Iarnr%C3%B3d%20%C3%89ireann">Iarnród Éireann</a> and the <a href="Taiwan%20Railway%20EMU100%20series">Taiwan Railway EMU100 series</a>. Rolling stock was also manufactured for <a href="Ghana%20Railway%20Corporation">Ghana</a>, <a href="Rail%20transport%20in%20Kenya">Kenya</a>, <a href="Rail%20transport%20in%20Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, and <a href="Rail%20transport%20in%20Tanzania">Tanzania</a>.
Other products.
BREL built prototypes such as the <a href="British%20Rail%20Class%20210">Class 210</a> <a href="diesel-electric%20multiple%20unit">DEMU</a> and the experimental high-speed <a href="Advanced%20Passenger%20Train">Advanced Passenger Train</a> (APT) <a href="tilting%20train">tilting train</a> during the 1970s and early 1980s. The Class 210 were externally very similar to the first batch of <a href="British%20Rail%20Class%20317">Class 317</a> EMUs, but half of the forward carriage was taken up by the engine room, where an above-floor diesel engine drove a generator to power traction motors on the axles.
